Situation1: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Situation2: They notice a few swimmers occasionally drifting toward deeper water but no immediate danger arises.
Story: I sat on my high lifeguard chair, the sun beating down on my shoulders, scanning the pool for any signs of trouble. My phone buzzed in my bag below—another message from Alex. We’d argued three times this week about money, and I knew he expected me to text back, to resolve things, to show I cared. But my job demanded my full attention; I was supposed to watch every swimmer, every second, no exceptions. A couple of kids drifted toward the deep end, not in danger yet, but I kept my eyes on them. My mind, though, kept drifting back to Alex’s words, the tension in his voice, the way he’d said, “You never make time for us.” I felt pulled in two directions—my duty to keep these swimmers safe, and my responsibility to fix things with Alex before the rift grew wider. My heart pounded as I stared at the water, torn between the whistle around my neck and the phone in my bag, knowing I couldn’t be both the girlfriend he needed and the lifeguard these swimmers depended on, not at the same time.
